text: Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. So in a four-month period your PSA went up one hundred percent. It doubled. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. So if it goes - you’re expected to go up fifty percent … for a year, two years Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So that’s the general, overall, design of the trial. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. And would and the ORIOLE study as they call it, is being run by one of the radiology oncologists called Dr. T. You’ll see his name here. And, the way that we would precede, if you wanted me to, is to after we have this conversation… to give you the consent form, read it very carefully. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And, on that particular day you would have read out any particular information about the trial and issue questions for him and his team. Um, and if those questions aren’t answered to your satisfaction go ahead and do that. Then after that you’ve basically completed the screening for randomization. Okay. So although the study is a randomized study, it’s not a blinded study. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But in the case of radiotherapy versus therapy,

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
